column4: Any suggestions for getting wpa_supplicant to run only when I tell it to?
look into wpacli
I've attempted to use wpa_cli, but every time I try, it says that it cannot connect to wpa_supplicant.
is wpa_supplicant set to run at startup?  / is it running as daemon?
apparently, it's running as a daemon with the '-u -s' options, which prevent me from running it like I should.
what part of it do you want to control?
I want to be able to run it with my config file I've set up.
it should read out of your /etc/wpa_supplicant.conf by default, you can install a program "services" to add or remove that kind of stuff
right, but when I looked at that location, wpa_supplicant.conf was empty, despite being connected to the wifi...
you might have to remove network manager to get it out of the way first
rather, ther wasn't a wpa_supplicant.conf - there was an entire folder with ifupdown.sh, etc.
I just removed everything related to Gnome.
you have to make your own it doesn't show up automatically
I get that -- here might be a better question: is there a way to have a stripped-down ubuntu installed? One without KDE/Gnome, but still have a "desktop" configuration?
Or do I need to switch over to server?
install debian ;)
really?
Debian will give you all the options to select exactly what you want
shouldnt be a problem since they both use apt
Ubuntu is just a preconfiged debian distro
ubuntu just has more repos but u can use any apt repo you want
debian is mostly internet install based
Even better. Thank you much!
